Problem:
class WeatherSimulator { constructor(weatherType) { this.weatherType = weatherType; } updateWeather(newWeatherType) { this.weatherType = newWeatherType; } reportWeather(feel) { if (feel === 'cold') { return this.weatherType === 'snowy' ? 'Stay warm!' : 'Dress properly!'; } else if (feel === 'hot') { return this.weatherType === 'sunny' ? 'Stay hydrated!' : 'Cool off!'; } else { return 'Enjoy your day!'; } } } const weather = new WeatherSimulator('sunny'); console.log(weather.reportWeather('hot')); weather.updateWeather('snowy'); console.log(weather.reportWeather('cold'));",

If we update the weatherType to 'rainy', will the WeatherSimulator report 'Cool off!' when feel is 'hot'?
Explanation: Changing the weatherType to 'rainy' directly influences the output of reportWeather method when feel is 'hot'. Since 'rainy' isn't associated with 'Stay hydrated!', the next conditional recognized is 'Cool off!'. This question explores the causal impact with intervention.
